PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, I refer to your glib and misleading denial yesterday that your dodgy figures on the contributions of American, Japanese and Danish students towards the cost of their higher education had been used in any way to justify the government's proposed changes to HECS. You went on to say:

QUESTION.PARA: Those figures were used merely to fill in the picture and give an indication of what charges were elsewhere.

How do you then explain that on page 8 of your own higher education budget statement of 9 August the only argumentation used in support of your HECS proposals are these very same dodgy figures—figures that your own department has admitted are unreliable and inappropriate? How can you possibly maintain this incorrect information? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins, I thank you for that question—although I have to admit a bit of bad faith in thanking you for it, because you have displayed yet again a complete incapacity on the part of the opposition to come up with anything new and address any serious questions. I do not know where you were, but that is not new; that is 9 August. We are in November now. Things have moved on.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator, if you were concentrating in the last sitting week, you would have noticed that I came into this place and indicated that I did not think that was the best table that could be relied on. At the same time, I tabled a minute from the department indicating what they saw in the table and I accompanied that with a copy of the actual table. I further indicated yesterday in an answer to Senator Bishop—

TALK.START.PARA: —O'Brien.

—Senator O'Brien. My humble apologies; you are new senators and I will get it right. I indicated yesterday that those figures had not been relied on in any way to come to the conclusion that the higher education contribution scheme charge should be increased. Those figures are in the statement as an indicative comparison for people to make an assessment.
—In this document?

—That is right, and that is what I said yesterday. You were good enough to repeat it today but, in doing so, you have strangely given me the opportunity to explain yet again why we want that charge to go up.
—You said new.

—No, it is not new. Senator Collins, have you looked at the minute that was tabled? Have you looked at the minute? Does that refer to these other nations? Does the minute refer to these other nations, Senator Collins? You do not know, do you? You have just been given a dummy sheet to ask a question from. You are asking a dixer. The question was asked yesterday and it was answered yesterday. But since you raise the question of HECS and the government's justification for asking the parliament to agree to adopt the HECS increase, let me repeat what I said yesterday.

BREAK.PARA: University students are amongst the luckiest people in the country. We give them roughly, at a minimum, $20,000 worth of higher education—far more than we give people who go to TAFE and far more than we give people who do a trade or an apprenticeship. We give university students a lot. We ask them only to make a contribution and to make it when they start earning an income. If you do not think that puts them in the luckiest category, fine. You go out and tell the tradespeople that it is right that they should pay for their tools but university students do not have to pay until they earn an income—an income of $28,000, as you would have it. You go ahead and do that.

But from where we come from, university students are amongst the luckiest school leavers. So it is fair enough, given the private benefit they get, to ask them to make a higher contribution. It is fair enough not only to ask for a higher contribution but to shift to the recommendation made by Neville Wran, the former Labor Premier of New South Wales, when he suggested that we have a differentiated HECS. We are not asking teachers, who do not get as much in the way of private benefit, to give as much per annum as doctors. If you think that is fair, you go out and argue it. But I will be out arguing the opposite case.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Let me quote this new example of how Senator Vanstone has misled the Senate. Her higher education budget statement says:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . on average, the HECS charge represents around 23% of the cost of a higher education course . . . The average proportion—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. Senator Collins has started by saying that she wishes to quote a new example. If she is quoting a new example, it can hardly be a matter arising out of the answer given by Senator Vanstone. Therefore, I submit that it cannot be a supplementary question.

—Madam President, on the point of order: Senator Collins asked Senator Vanstone a question relating to—I think she mentioned it in her question—page 8 of a higher education budget statement. Senator Collins is now asking a supplementary question, quoting from that selfsame higher education budget statement. —Madam President, I go back to what I said was the new example cited in my original question. Minister, your higher education budget statement says:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins, I do not know whether you understand this but you have not added anything, not a thing, by your supplementary, so I have got nothing to add.

—My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston. Has the minister seen reports of the $US24 billion merger between British Telecom and MCI? What lessons does this merger hold for Telstra? Does it show that players in the telecommunications market are facing unprecedented global competition? And does it also show that privatisation has been a critical part of British Telecom's success in this ever more competitive market?
—Order! There is too much conversation in the chamber. I do not know whether Senator Alston heard that question.
—He wrote it!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not taken entirely by surprise, and I am grateful to Senator Macdonald. But I would have thought everyone in this chamber would have been asking this question, because it is a very important issue that is going to confront this parliament very shortly.

ANSWER.PARA: The merger of BT and MCI is of the order of $US24 billion. In other words, this is a mega‐merger amongst mega‐mergers. What it amounts to is that both of these very substantial international players recognise that it is necessary to get together, to combine, to compete effectively in the new international environment. What is particularly significant, in terms of assessment of this merger, is a piece by Glenda Korporaal in today's Sydney Morning Herald. She said:
After 12 years of privatisation, BT has been transformed into a much stronger, more efficient company, set to become one of the dominant international telecommunications players of the next century.

A domestically‐focused, government‐owned BT could never have dreamed of pulling off the megadeal British Telecom has put its name to over the weekend. It's not just the financial ability for a merger provided by a stockmarket listing; it is the whole gamut of operational efficiencies made possible by being freed of political masters and the more entrepreneurial, competitive leading‐edge managerial culture which is allowed to develop in a corporation that reports to shareholders rather than politicians.
She goes on to say:

Far from being threatened or weakened by privatisation, the experience has allowed BT to take a hard-headed look at its cost structure and recruit the kind of internationally‐minded chief executive . . .
She then goes on to talk about the extent of the debate in other countries and how the privatisation of telcos is in fact sweeping the world.
If one looks at Chanticleer in today's Financial Review, we find more of the same. The Chanticleer article says:
The BT takeover of MCI is a function of the collapse of barriers to entry in most of the major telecommunications markets around the world.
It further states:
. . . barriers to competition . . . have crumbled to the point of no return.
Thus Telstra Corp—which is medium sized and medium‐tech by global standards—has reached a critical turning point. It is going to come under unprecedented assault in its home market . . .
But the consequences for Telstra of remaining 100 per cent government‐owned while competing in the Australian market with the likes of AT&T from next year could be severe.
What we have here is a very eloquent outlining of what I think are overwhelming reasons. Indeed, these reasons are recognised around the world.

The tragedy is that on the other side we have a bunch of dinosaurs who are somehow determined to ensure that Australia remains behind the main game, remains less than fully internationally competitive. Over the other side you have probably the largest sandpit in history. You have 28 or 29 of them over there all putting their collective heads in the sand, not prepared to face up to a very serious issue other than by way of people like Mr Beazley saying very smugly, `There is nothing much left to privatise.'

I would have thought that, with that sort of attitude, they ought to be in the Guinness Book of Records for being either the biggest sandpit in history or, indeed, the biggest bunch of political hypocrites in history. Quite clearly, they understand the virtues of privatisation, they know this would be good for Australia, they know it would be good for consumers, they know it would be good for subscribers and ordinary Australians; but, for base‐minded political motives, they are simply not prepared to do what they have done on all government business enterprises to date. Australia is the worst for this political myopia. Quite clearly, Australian consumers will suffer; Australia's international image will suffer. I just hope they will find the time to read at least those two pieces and understand the compelling logic behind them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. How are Telstra's prospects prejudiced in this increasingly competitive world if it remains 100 per cent government owned?
—Did that take you by surprise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for that very challenging question. Telstra will indeed be handicapped in a number of very important ways. Quite clearly, it needs to have market accountability. It needs a share price which sends a day-to-day signal to investors, the board and management, to make them aware of how the company is travelling—not just reporting from time to time to government, as it does now, where the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, could call in the managing director and basically say, `Give us another $300 million or $400 million to fix my budget bottom line.'
—But you just stacked the board with your mates. You can call them in now.
—I don't recall anyone else saying that to date. Indeed, everyone else has said—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I'm sorry, I can't hear you. The fact is that the board is a very high quality outfit. It is one of the few things we have had the capacity to do in recent times prior to the partial privatisation, and I think it will make a significant difference. But there is a long way to go. (Time expired)

—I ask Senator Hill in his own portfolio and representing tourism: has the minister been made aware of a media release from the Tourism Council of Australia of 31 October concerning the uncertainty surrounding the 500 per cent increase in the reef tax? The TCA Chairman, Bruce Baird, is quoted as saying that this issue has reached a critical stage because several contract negotiations for reef tours with overseas wholesalers have been cancelled as a result of this uncertainty. Do you have any intention to address the concerns of the tourism industry and remove the uncertainty created by this issue? When will you announce your backdown on this issue?

—I think the honourable senator is referring to the environment management charge that was first introduced by the Labor government at $1 which we announced in the budget would be increased to $6—about the cost of a hamburger, Senator Cook, I might say. It was pursuant to a practice that is being adopted by governments throughout Australia and internationally, and that is that major conservation reserves, principally national parks, should be costed in a way that the burden is borne between both taxpayers at large and the users of the park. We believe that the users of this park should pay a greater share, and that is the rationale behind the decision that we made.

BREAK.PARA: As I have said to you before, Senator, subsequent to the budget decision and the estimates, the industry did come to us with certain administrative concerns. As I have also said to you before, those administrative concerns are being addressed and, if and when we have anything further to add in relation to that matter, we will let them know.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't ring us; we'll ring you. Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the statement by the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation that hundreds of small tourism operators were being threatened and potentially forced out of business because of this massive 500 per cent reef tax hike, why don't you junk the tax instead of junking the industry?

—That is highly imaginative. Of course, that is consistent with Labor's view that the taxpayer should bear more. No, it was Labor in fact that left us with a deficit of nearly $10,000 million, so I am not surprised that Senator Cook is now, from the position of opposition, revising his view and believing that the users of the park should pay less and the taxpayers should pay more. In relation to the wellbeing of small business, I can tell you, Senator Cook, with lower interest rates, lower taxation, lower inflation—
—Thanks to us.
—Thanks to the coalition government, small business will do a lot better than it did under you.

—My question is addressed to Senator Newman representing the Minister for Health. Will the minister outline measures being undertaken to improve the standard of general practice in Australia, and will after hours medical services be improved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister Wooldridge, of course, has the responsibility for this area of policy but has always had a strong reputation for his support for improving the standards of medical practice, particularly in general practice. The recent budget confirmed the government's support also for Australia's highly prized tradition of family medicine centred on the general practitioner. We have sought to increase the status of general practice as a calling, partly by retaining some existing measures and partly by introducing some innovations of our own.

ANSWER.PARA: We have retained the general practice strategy with funding being maintained at $224 million, reversing a savings decision made during the election campaign. That includes the better practice program, the rural incentives program, funding for divisions of general practice, and also the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners training program which provides 400 training places for young doctors. This government is intent on reshaping these program elements to better target quality and good outcomes. We will therefore be putting in place a comprehensive review of the general practice strategy to deliver the best opportunities for GPs, including part‐time doctors and women practitioners.

I am advised that there is considerable scope to re‐target the better practice program which provides formula‐based grants to practices assessed against a set of benchmarking criteria, taking into account concerns of the profession about how the program currently operates. The BPP gives eligible practices a revenue complement for fees for service.

One of the options that the minister is particularly interested in is payment for after hours care. As you would be aware, the conduct of home visits and participation in after hours care are current eligibility requirements for the program. Certainly at the moment the program does not adequately reward practices which have on call or deputising services. This is something the government wants to look at in conjunction with the medical profession for, if the returns are inadequate, locum and deputising services will continue to be underused.

The senator may also be interested in questions of access to primary medical care in rural and remote areas of Australia. It is certainly an issue in Western Australia, Senator Panizza, as you well know, just as it is in my own state of Tasmania.

While there is a national oversupply of several thousand GPs, in country Australia there is an undersupply of several hundred. As part of the medical work force package introduced in the budget, temporary visa doctors and new graduates will be able to work in the country as rural locums through approved placements. These placements will ensure that appropriate supervisory quality assurance and backup arrangements are in place.

The government's overall medical work force strategy is consistent with its commitment to quality general practice. By restricting access to Medicare only to those doctors with postgraduate training or those on a training program, the government is treating general practice with the respect it deserves. This government values general practice. It wants to see it survive and grow in a professional environment increasingly dominated by specialisation.

We are keen to address the general oversupply situation, but we are also just as keen to do something about the poor distribution of the GPs we already have. We have announced that we will take a strategic view of the problem, offering short-term and long-term measures which over time will address the pressures of the provision of medical services.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABC: Televising of Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, have you written to Mr Brian Johns, Managing Director of the ABC, asking the ABC either to delay or abandon its TV coverage of the Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras; why shouldn't Australia's gay community have their major social event carried on the national broadcaster; since when has the minister for communications had the right to interfere in the program decisions of the ABC; and have you raised this matter with Mr Donald McDonald, the Chairman of the ABC?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I did write to Brian Johns on 22 October. I wrote to him in terms of an inquiry, not in any shape or form seeking to impose a personal view, and certainly recognising that programming is the sole responsibility of the ABC. I did this on the basis of about 60 letters that have been received by my department since the beginning of the year, most of those calling for the program to be taken off air completely but a number of others simply asking for it to be rescheduled.

ANSWER.PARA: The purpose of my letter was simply to inquire and to seek advice on behalf of constituents and members of the general public who choose to write to me on the issue so that I can properly inform them about the current state of play. There is nothing exceptional about that; there is nothing unusual. Indeed, I would have thought it is a dereliction of duty not to ensure that the minister is fully informed about decisions that are of consequence and of interest to those who write in. That is simply what I did.

I asked Mr Johns to advise me whether or not the ABC had any plans to take the program off air or to reschedule it to a later time slot. In that context, I do not think anyone would construe that as me somehow leaning on the ABC or trying to tell them what ought to happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you table the letter?
—I am happy to table the letter. I mean, the letter consists of three paragraphs. It reads:

ANSWER.PARA: I write concerning the telecast by the ABC of the Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras. I have received a significant number of complaints regarding the screening of the Mardi Gras, copies of which I have referred to you.
As you would be aware, in 1994 a large number of parliamentarians including myself—
and, I might add, including a number of people from your side of the chamber—
signed a petition requesting that the ABC re‐schedule the program to a later timeslot than 8.30 p.m.
Given the significant level of community concern over the years, could you advise whether the ABC is proposing to reconsider telecasting the event or at least broadcasting it in a later timeslot?
Quite clearly, this was not seeking to impose any personal view and was not trying to argue the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, no!

—If it had been, I would have been writing to him on day one, wouldn't I? I would have been making sure that they understood that we did have a view on the matter. It was only after I received a significant number of letters from a number of people on the issue that I thought it was desirable to inform myself and to take the matter forward so that I could properly respond.

—I direct a supplementary question to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. I almost got the impression that you were writing to them on a constituent matter as a senator from Victoria. Do you see a problem or any potential problem in a misunderstanding at the ABC when the minister writes rather than you in your role as a senator for Victoria; secondly, can the minister indicate on how many other occasions—or was there any occasion—you have written to the ABC about programming matters on the basis of letters sent to you as minister for communications?
—I do not think people were writing to me as a senator for Victoria; they were writing to me as the minister.
—There you go.

—There you go, that is right. Out you go. They were asking me what the position was. In fact, many of them were arguing in very trenchant terms about their opposition to the issue. I have sent on each of those letters—that is the standard practice. They have each gone to Mr Johns individually. I cannot tell you off hand how many other letters. I would be prepared to go—
—Have a guess. None?

—No. There have been a large number of complaints about three or four programs in particular. I think question time was one of them. They were appalled at your attitude to Telstra. But I have generally ignored that because I thought the point had been well made. There have been a number of programs on which the ABC has actually indicated to me that, with hindsight, they thought their approach had been inappropriate and they have apologised. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. I ask the minister: is he one of the federal government ministers who, according to a report in today's Financial Review , believes that the overhaul of federal-state responsibilities has foundered; doesn't this failure represent a considerable threat to a foundation stone of the government's budget strategy, that is, shifting costs to the state but not revenue; and doesn't it represent an even greater threat to those ordinary Australians who rely on some community assistance in the areas of health, aged care and housing and who are now, it seems to me, caught in the COAG crossfire?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for the question, Senator Kernot. As you would be aware, there are continuing discussions with the states on these types of issues. I would not wish to give any preview or comment on the state of those particular negotiations. But, on the general issue, we are very proud of the budget which we have brought down. That budget has been described as a fair budget. It has been widely accepted in the community. Judging by recent polls, the community acceptance of the budget is extremely good.

ANSWER.PARA: We believe that, in discussions with the states and with the budget we have brought down, we are effectively addressing community concerns. If there is anything I can add to those matters, I will come back to you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, if you fail to persuade your conservative state colleagues to accept this cost shifting, won't your budget stand to fail? You have relied so much on this—shifting the cost, none of the responsibility—that your budget looks doomed, doesn't it? If you cannot deliver now, when you have the best opportunity with your conservative colleagues on your conservative agenda, is next week's COAG meeting doomed to fail to deliver this substantial part of your budget?

—As often happens in question time, there is a tendency to exaggerate and perhaps beg the question. We will be having discussions with our colleagues and I am sure that those discussions will be extremely constructive.

—My question is directed to Senator Alston representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can you confirm that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Reith, in briefing your own backbench committee on 14 October, raised the following issues: the need to encourage more private sector practice in the public sector; a wide‐ranging review of leave and allowance payments; and the need for more direct relationships between public servants and management? Did Mr Reith raise this secret agenda during his negotiations with the Australian Democrats on the workplace relations bill? And how did Mr Reith respond to a question from Mr Stewart McArthur as to whether the Commonwealth government would use Victoria's public service reforms as a model?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —That question seems to require me, firstly, to have been at a briefing of the backbench committee on industrial relations, which I was not; secondly, to have attended a meeting with Democrats, which I did not; and, thirdly, to have been present when Mr Reith answered the question from Mr McArthur, and I was not.
—You are representing him.

—I do represent him, but that was not the question. I can represent him on policy issues but I am being asked about my physical presence. I am being asked whether I was there and whether he did certain things. The answer is that I do not know.

ANSWER.PARA: If you are going to ask a question which, transparently, is unable to be answered, you deserve to have it pointed out to you that you should not ask it in those terms. I am not expected to know those things. I was not present at the Democrats' briefing. Why would I be at a backbench meeting of the industrial relations committee? I am happy to take those matters back to Mr Reith and to see whether he can help you. If you want to pursue some conspiracy theory about issues being put to the Democrats and put to the backbench committee, I will see if Mr Reith can assist you, but I would be very surprised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I should start my supplementary question by asking the minister whether he is, in fact, the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations in this chamber, but his hesitancy in confirming the briefing—I have referred directly to leaked minutes from that meeting—exposes the government's public facade on industrial relations has having no relationship whatsoever with its real industrial agenda. Minister, can you guarantee that Mr Reith's briefing of the backbench committee in no way contradicts Mr Howard's promise that no worker will be worse off after the workplace relations bill has been passed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I made it perfectly clear that, whilst I might be the minister representing Mr Reith, I am not expected to have been present at every briefing session he might have. The real point of your question is to bag the Democrats. You are saying that the Democrats were hoodwinked; the Democrats did not have the ability to analyse the bill for themselves.

ANSWER.PARA: The Democrats are not being asked to take our word for certain things. They are being asked to support the passage of a particular piece of legislation. They can read the matter for themselves. They can get expert advice. They can understand it themselves. They have made a considered judgment, and you do not like it.

You are trying to say to the Democrats, `You've been hoodwinked; you've been misled. Mr Reith's telling another story.' The fact is, you judge legislation on its face. You do not judge it on what people might say to you in the public bar or in a private meeting with a few of your mates. You judge it on its merits, and I have no doubt that that is what the Democrats have done and that is why you do not like their position. I understand that you are accountable to your political masters—they do not like it much either—but as far as we are concerned the Democrats can make their own judgment. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to Senator Vanstone in her capacity as the Minister representing the Attorney‐General. The minister would recall that on 23 May this year I asked a question on notice relating to the international transfer of prisoners. Part of the answer to my question advised that Commonwealth legislation on this issue was expected to be introduced during 1996. Could the minister advise whether it is still expected that the relevant legislation will be introduced this year, and when does the government expect that the first transfer of prisoners will occur?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Colston for his question, of which he gave notice to the office of the Attorney‐General. I am pleased to advise that the Attorney‐General still expects that the Commonwealth legislation will be introduced this year. Recently, there was a quite important step in progressing Australia's participation in the arrangements for the transfer of prisoners. That is, with the exception of the Northern Territory and subject to final confirmation from one jurisdiction, all other state and territory attorney‐generals have endorsed draft legislation for the transfer of prisoners at the meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorney‐Generals.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposed legislation would allow Australians serving prison sentences overseas and foreign nationals imprisoned in Australian prisons to return to their home countries to complete their sentences. Endorsement of the draft legislation is seen as something of a major step. However, the Attorney‐General is unable to specify exactly when the first transfer would be able to occur. Before any transfers can take place, obviously, the legislation has to pass through the federal and relevant state and territory parliaments. A number of administrative steps also will need to be taken and transfer arrangements will have to be made with other countries.

In view of the humanitarian, economic and social advantages of international prisoner transfer schemes, the Attorney advises that the Commonwealth will certainly be working to have the scheme operating as quickly as possible. To that end, the Attorney advises that the Commonwealth intends to introduce this legislation before the end of this year. The Commonwealth will also be encouraging the participating states and territories to enact their complementary legislation as soon as is reasonably possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Are you aware that, at a Senate estimate committee hearing in September, your departmental officer Mr Whalan stated that the department, during the time of the Labor government, had `some discussions . . . with superannuation funds about their attitude to investment in low cost housing in particular' but stopped short of stating that you or anyone in your government had had any such discussions? You stated yesterday in your answer to a dorothy dixer on housing:

QUESTION.PARA: The solution is to involve the private sector more, both in capital funding of public housing and also in the provision in the private sector.

Minister, which private sector representatives have you had discussions with in an effort to secure their involvement? Has anyone involved in formulating the new Commonwealth‐state housing policy actually ascertained the likelihood of large‐scale, quality, private sector housing construction for low income Australians—a sector of the market not renowned for large‐scale returns? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McKiernan for his question. The department has advised me that discussions have taken place over the last year or so with some of the superannuation funds which have indeed expressed interest in low cost housing. I have had informal discussions with some merchant banks over involvement in financing of low cost housing. Interest has been expressed to me. At this stage, these matters have not been progressed further because they are, in many ways, dependent upon the progress of the COAG reforms on housing.

ANSWER.PARA: There is obviously a need to improve the quality of public housing in Australia, a responsibility which is the states. There are various mechanisms by which additional public housing can be financed, and the private sector has an interest in being involved in that in some respects.

BREAK.PARA: We are often told by community advocates that it is difficult to get the private sector to invest in low cost housing. This is an area which I am keen to encourage the private sector to take an interest in and to be involved in. I have had discussions with the Housing Industry Association and the Real Estate Institute of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for her answer. Minister, could you add to your answer by citing some examples where individual large‐scale private sector investors have got into the low cost housing provision market, or are planning to do so? Or is it true, in the words of your department, that very little low income rental accommodation is purpose‐built, apart from public housing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not prepared to actually identify particular organisations because the discussions that have been held to date have been confidential ones. Nevertheless, there are some of the financial institutions in Australia which are investing in low cost housing in our region.
—`In our region'; what does that mean?
—I can only hope that their interest in investing in our region could be translated to investing in their own country. That is something which I will be pursuing as the reforms progress.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
Question Without Notice of Senator Cooney to Senator Vanstone representing the Attorney‐General on 4 November 1996

I refer to the Commonwealth initiatives to establish a uniform defamation code across Australia. What are the implications of this proposal for publication on the Internet? Is it the Government's intention to extend common law libel protection to Internet publications? What advice, if any, has the Commonwealth received on the jurisdictional issues involved in such a proposal?
Response of Senator Vanstone on behalf of the Attorney‐General

. Yesterday the Honourable Senator Cooney directed a number of questions to the Minister representing the Attorney‐General in relation to Government's agenda for defamation law reform. I undertook to answer those questions on the Attorney's behalf.

. This Government acknowledges that it is unacceptable in this age of modern communications that citizens of one jurisdiction have greater freedom to speak out than citizens of a neighbouring jurisdiction.
. Although defamation law is primarily a matter for the States and Territories, this Government therefore, strongly supports the development of uniform national defamation laws.

. Defamation law reform and questions of choice of law are currently under consideration by the Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General and my colleague the Attorney‐General will continue to urge the States and Territories to reach agreement on a uniform defamation law and relevant issues of choice of law. A uniform approach to defamation would address such national implications as publication on the internet has in this area.

. The Honourable Senator's question suggests that under the current law, there is a void in protection in relation to internet publications. While the situation must be closely monitored reform must be measured and respond to demonstrable need. The Senator might not be aware of the report on legal issues prepared by the previous Government's National Information Services Council. That report indicated that the belief that the technological revolution embodied in the information superhighway of necessity entails the need for a legal revolution of the same magnitude is an unnecessary and panic response that should not be taken too seriously. Overall, the Council recommended that care should be taken that there is no undue rush into legislation where none is needed.

. In the area of censorship generally, the Government is developing a proposal for on‐line content regulation in light of a recent report of the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) on content issues in the broader telecommunications environment.

. The Government has foreshadowed the establishment of a national regulatory framework in this area which will be based on industry developed codes of practice with the ABA as industry regulator. I understand that there will be a broad public consultation on the nature of the national scheme at an early stage.
. This Government will therefore continue to monitor developments in this area and will respond where appropriate, as the Government is now doing in relation to privacy law reform.

BREAK.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), to a question without notice asked by Senator Cook today, relating to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority environmental management charge.

Between Pauline Hanson and this government there has been a big effort to undermine the Australian tourist industry. In the case of Pauline Hanson you can say that is a special factor, although the government must share some of the blame in not responding to her directly and unambiguously, sooner than it did.

My remarks this afternoon are about the tourism industry and government steps that have been taken in the budget which impose new taxes and costs on that tourist industry and undermine the ability of smaller operators in the industry to effectively compete in what is one of Australia's most premier tourist locations, the Great Barrier Reef.

The tourist industry in Australia is one of the fastest growing industries we have in this country. Australia is rightly world famous as a tourist destination and for the magnificent scenery we offer international visitors. Tourism, as a facet of the Australian economy, is one of the biggest earners of foreign exchange of any, and is one of the reasons why services exports for Australia show a huge growth. It is one of the industry sectors that is most active in turning back the current account deficit.

Cynics in the tourist industry say that Australia is known overseas for three things: the reef, the rock and the Opera House; and that foreign tourists come to Australia primarily to see those three attractions. I do not wish to comment on that other than to say that what that remark does underline absolutely is the importance of the Great Barrier Reef to Australian tourism. It is one of the world famous natural phenomena that bolsters Australia's income. The Great Barrier Reef is also one of the few things that you can actually see from the moon.

With respect to the Great Barrier Reef, in the last budget the government increased charges for reef visits—the infamous reef tax—by 500 per cent. The interesting thing about the budget was that it was supposed to have made savings in order that the budget could come more sharply into balance. But it is a curious piece of accounting to tax an industry which is a growth industry, thus stunting its growth so it will not grow as fast and so the government will not receive in the budget income from employed persons in the form of PAYE tax or will not receive from companies which would otherwise have grown more rapidly than the tax would allow, income to the budget from the point of view of corporate tax or company tax.

So what we have is a narrowly defined accountant's view that if it is a tax, increase it. That is what happened in this budget. But do not have regard to the earning capacity of the whole industry and the total advantage that industry is to the Australian community in employment, job creation and earning foreign exchange in growing companies, and in allowing small businesses that base themselves on tourism to prosper; and do not account for the advantage that gives to the income side of the budget.

This is, in the classic case, one of the most short‐sighted things a government can do—not look at the total impact, just increase a tax and stand back and not worry. There is reason to worry and the reason is best articulated by the people in this industry. Operators in the Australian tourist industry, particularly those on the Great Barrier Reef, rightly have been complaining. This tax, in many cases, has caused international contracts not to be renewed. This tax has meant that small operators who put their prices in their pricing packages months in advance now have to go and reprint and reorganise their pricing charges. In some cases that is bad for business. If they do not do it they will go under; if they do do it they will lose traffic and trade—and the impact is something the whole economy will feel.

When the reef tax was first imposed there was understandably an outcry by tourist operators in Australia. One would have expected a sensitive government to pay attention to this because it does mean jobs for Australians, it does mean income to the tax side of the ledger as well and it would mean that a government that paid attention to the needs of this industry was listening to what the people said. But has this government paid attention? No. Today we heard from the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) representing, of all people, the minister for tourism, say, `We'll ring you, don't ring us,' to this industry. He said, `You have made representations. We will take them on board and we will get back to you if we choose.' (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not happen, Margaret. Don't waste your precious time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on this issue because I think there are a number of myths that have been perpetrated this afternoon about the issue of the reef tax. The first thing that I want to allude to is the fact that when the then Leader of the Opposition launched the tourist policy, it was launched in Cairns on the promise that there would be no additional taxes in the tourist industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The tourist operators in the north took that very much to heart. I have had the pleasure of travelling to Cairns and meeting with tourist operators, who have expressed to me their bitter disappointment that the government reneged on that issue, in particular by upping the reef tax, as it now has become known, to the tune of 500 per cent.

I think one should look at what exactly the reef tax is. When this charge was introduced by the former Labor government, it was an environmental management charge of $1. That charge of $1 was to do nothing else than to assist research on our most important wonder—the reef. Of the $1, 75c went to the Cooperative Research Centre For Ecologically Sustainable Development of the Great Barrier Reef. In other words, the money was put into research and development associated with the reef. The other 25c of the original dollar, of the environmental management charge, went to GBRMPA, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, as a management collection charge to assist in the collection of the $1 at the various points from the operators.

It was never under any circumstances a direct tax because the operators, when it was originally mooted by the former Labor government, were quite adamant that they did not want to be taxed; they did not want a tax but they would go along with the concept of an environmental management charge, which would go very much to research on the reef. That is the way it has been interpreted by the local operators up there and that is what they believed it would be. So when the government came along and upped it by 500 per cent and used it to no other purpose other than to fund GBRMPA and to relieve the funding of GBRMPA, it then became a tax on them, and it was a tax that they could not bear.

The tax has been compared to the charges to enter national parks but of course there is no relationship at all between the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and other land based national parks. So the charge cannot be in any way equated with the charges on the mainland for other great national parks that we have.

The real problem facing the tourist operators up there is the fact that they have had to advertise their prices and fix their prices out to April 1998. That is a substantial period ahead and, if those prices are not fixed, then they lose their credibility in the international tourist market. That is the problem that is confronting the tourist operators because they are the ones who have to pay the tax. It is not a tax that is directly collected from the individual who visits the reef on a day-to-day basis; it is something that is built into the price. To change their price structures now would, in effect, destroy their credibility.

This becomes the concern of these small operators, these small business people. I was led to believe, when I met with people from the Far North Queensland Promotion Bureau, who have some 700 members, that the substantial majority of their members are involved in one way or another in the tourist industry, two‐thirds of them are small businesses with five or fewer than five staff, and 80 per cent of their membership have 20 staff or less. So what we are facing here is a crisis for small business. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —On the same issue, there is an irony here in relation to the charges for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park inasmuch as it seems to me that, if you think of the proposed sale of Telstra and why that should be required to fund the environment, the environment is being picked out as the area which should be self‐funded, should have individual ways of being funded which are not out of the general revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it both ironic and dangerous that the environment is picked out as being that one area which is user-pays and at the same time has its funding that would normally come out of general revenue pulled out. This is not the first time we have seen this happen. We saw it in the lead in petrol debate in 1993 where the ALP did something similar. It suggested that funding could go to the environment, but at the same time it pulled money out of the environment portfolio and simply swapped it with another general revenue raising measure.

I would like to think this measure will not be the general picture—that every time we want to raise a bit of extra money and put it into general revenue, we are going to find some way of looking like we are raising money for the environment while all we are doing is ripping money out of the environment and expecting the environment to pay for itself.

The irony here is that perhaps the pressures on GBRMPA—the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority—have made it act a bit like the Department of Conservation and Land Management in Western Australia. Why are there parallels between these two organisations? We have heard just this week that there are proposals from some forces within GBRMPA to have a trial on some of their reefs to see what happens when you fish out pristine reefs or just fish enough for them to be damaged—to see to what point you can fish them until they are damaged.

The parallel here is that it is very similar to what happens in the Department of Conservation and Land Management. The small royalties that the Department of Conservation and Land Management gets from the use of clear-felling of native forests actually go towards their running expenses. It becomes a perpetual motion machine. You have to keep ripping out native forests in order for the Department of Conservation and Land Management—the department which oversees the ripping out of those native forests—to continue.

I would hate to think we have a situation where the destruction of the reef becomes the rationale for the continuation of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. I would hate to think we will start looking at royalties for fishing and recreation. That decision in the long run—just like the decisions that I believe CALM are making in Western Australia—will be to the detriment of tourism and the environment.

In that instance, it is really not necessary to conduct 11 experiments in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, because these experiments are being conducted all around the Pacific to the detriment of everybody. In fact, because the reefs fertilise each other, we are also putting at risk the reef systems right around the area.

If we are concerned about short-sighted decisions relating to tourism, we must also add this other Great Barrier Reef short-sighted decision. If we as a parliament let it go by—so that we oversee an `experiment' which does not need to occur: that is, to see what happens when you fish out a reef or damage a reef, its environs and its fishing—we are doing worse than our proposal to make the Great Barrier Reef pay for itself.

There are problems with that, and there are a number of issues involved in requiring the environment to be self-funded. If you ask people—as EPAC did within the last 12 months or so—what they think their taxes should be spent on, amongst those issues which they strongly support are the maintenance and good quality of the environment.

I think it is a dangerous track we are running down—this idea that the environment should pay for itself via special levies and that a body like the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has to find other sources of funding. If that were to occur, there could be a conflict of interest—just like with foresters at the Department of Conservation and Land Management—so that harvesting the reef would become the source of revenue. We have two issues here and they ought to both be addressed; otherwise we will kill the goose that laid the golden egg.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 182, relating to East Timorese asylum seekers be taken as formal.
—Is there any objection?
—Yes.
—Pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

BREAK.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Brown moving a motion relating to the conduct of business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 182.

I move this motion because this matter is urgent. The motion before the Senate seeks to allay the anxiety of 1,500 East Timorese asylum seekers who are in Australia and who want to maintain their protection, their security, their safety and their peace of mind in this country.

My motion calls on the government to create a humanitarian visa for the 1,500 East Timorese asylum seekers in this country. It aims to repeat the special protection given by the government to the many Chinese students in this country at the time of Tiananmen Square, when a special provision was made under the then Labor government for those Chinese students who were in fear for their safety, their wellbeing and their lives if they were at that time forced back to China so that they could have permanent residency in Australia. If those circumstances warranted that, surely the circumstances confronting the people of East Timor who have fled to the safety of this country deserve no less.

This is a very urgent matter. A couple of months ago, many of these people received a letter from the department of immigration which indicated that they were about to be deported on the basis that they were Portuguese. These are people who have never been to Portugal. Most of them do not speak Portuguese. They have no affinity except what they have read in the history books about the previous Portuguese colonial administration in their country.

They are also people who, as citizens of East Timor, have very often stood up to the military occupation of their country. For that, they can live in fear of their lives. For that, they have been forced to leave our nearest neighbour, the country of East Timor. The plight of these people now in Australia with this threat of deportation hanging over their heads is indeed a harrowing and pitiable situation to hear about. At the outset, this government ought to maintain the stand it took in opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Brown is addressing the substantive motion. I want to hear why it is so urgent to be suspending standing orders.

—I have been listening to the debate, and it seems to me that Senator Brown was debating the urgency of the matter. To do that, occasionally he has to bring in the substantive issue. I think at this stage Senator Brown is in order.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. The urgency for this matter would not be there had the Minister for Foreign Affairs kept to his statement of 11 October last year, when he said that the claim that the East Timorese asylum seekers are Portuguese is simply absurd and hypocritical. If it was absurd and hypocritical in October last year for Mr Downer, surely it is absurd and hypocritical that they are threatened with deportation as Portuguese citizens in November this year. If there were consistency in the government's policy on this matter and in their commitment to these 1,500 special citizens of Australia, as I would class them, then they would not be living in fear for their safety. They would not be living in anxiety. They would not be living with the axe over their heads with no choice but to go to Portugal, where they do not speak the language and where many of them do not share the culture or religion, or to go back to Indonesia.

BREAK.PARA: Let me give the case of one particular person amongst their number who came here in 1984. I am again pointing out the urgency of the matter for this person. During the occupation of East Timor, he witnessed his brother, aged 11, being killed outside his house. His father was killed. He fled, after being arrested and imprisoned for five months for passing on some notes and pictures to visiting journalists in 1994. Since then, Indonesian soldiers have entered his house and beaten his mother to death. Since then, one of his sisters has been raped. Since then, and just this year, two of his sisters have managed to escape to this country. All three of those people, after having escaped that hell under Indonesian occupation, are suddenly faced with Australia—this country, this land of the free, the land of democracy—deporting them to Portugal. The Senate should support this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition does not support the suspension of standing orders to bring forward this motion. We believe the issues contained in parts of the motion moved by Senator Brown are important. But he has two different views mixed in this resolution. One, in great detail, is about the issue of qualification for refugees to come to Australia. There are several paragraphs in great detail, but at the end the motion refers to the Nobel Peace Prize winners, about which the Senate has already declared its position and on which it has voted. The motion then calls on the government to create a humanitarian visa class for East Timorese asylum seekers. We believe there is a mixture of issues that, quite frankly, should be dealt with in a much wider debate.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, these sorts of issues should be dealt with, if necessary, by a standing committee of the Senate looking at the issues contained in this motion. Senator Brown has raised a very significant suggestion: the creation of a humanitarian visa class for East Timorese asylum seekers who applied before October 1996. There are probably 30 countries around the world that you could make an equally just case for giving a particular humanitarian class of refugee status to.

Only today I met a group of people from Sri Lanka, the Tamils, asking for the direct issue of humanitarian problems to be dealt with. Again, people from that part of Sri Lanka which the Tamils inhabit want to get applications for visas to come to Australia. You could make just as needy a case for those people as you can for East Timor.

The issues raised by Senator Brown are profound. I am not denying that at all. But I think the Senate would not be able to do the issues justice in a short debate brought on under this motion. If Senator Brown wants to refer a number of these issues to the appropriate committee—either the Senate standing references committee covering foreign affairs or the joint committee on migration regulations—I think that would be a much better place for this matter to be dealt with; rather than having a hurried debate here on a mixture of issues that, in many cases, are far too broad to be dealt with under a general notice of motion. We oppose the suspension of standing orders for those reasons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators would have noticed that I denied formality on this motion. The reason for denying formality was that I wanted to hear the arguments from not only Senator Brown but both the government and the opposition. It seemed fairly obvious from the whips meeting that neither the government nor the opposition had any intention of supporting the motion. It seems to be the current case that declaring a motion formal and voting against it is a way of stopping even hearing the arguments on a debate.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an urgent motion because human lives are at stake. There are very few examples where it is relatively easy to check the bona fides of people who are seeking refugee status for various reasons. Australia has been tiptoeing. As Senator Brown mentioned, the interesting thing is how the tables turn so quickly when someone has gone from being in opposition to being in government.

I thought and hoped that there might still be some conscience within members of the ALP and at least to have some understanding of how Australia is looking on the international arena in relation to these issues. This was one of the reasons why countries would not in a pink fit support Australia for a position on the Security Council: it continues to be so hypocritical on an issue so close to Australia for which we should have access to the information.

It is urgent because the people's lives are dependent on this action. Their lives may well be at risk. There is no valid reason in any ethical or moral sense why they should not be classified as refugees. The only thing I can think of, which is why it is so urgent for us to talk about it, is that Australia does not want to risk our market to Indonesia. I would think countries would be respected if they did not shillyshally around on these kinds of things which are in Australia's aegis.

BREAK.PARA: These are not internal matters. These are people who have a valid reason for seeking refugee status. We in Australia have the ability to make up our own minds. It is not interfering with anybody else's internal matters. Pushing the matter on to Portugal is not the right thing to do.

It is urgent that this Senate indicates to the government that it is time they took their responsibilities seriously. This is the only way that this can be done quickly. What kind of quick resolution could we get from, as Senator Schacht has suggested, a standing committee in the Senate—which one?—because how many are not flat tack at the moment; when would we get an answer; and what would that mean to the lives of those people in the meantime?

Certainly in the long run we do have to deal with this issue honestly and fully in the Senate. If there is a Senate standing committee that is prepared to look at it, perhaps Senator Schacht might be able to recommend it to us. That will not necessarily help those people whose lives are currently in jeopardy at the moment.

I would like to see some better response from the ALP. I would certainly like to have seen a better response from the government in this very urgent situation that we see now. These people had to leave for their own lives and for the fact that their lives will be in danger if they return. They deserve to be given basic humanitarian consideration. That is why it is urgent. That is why it will be very disappointing if the Senate does not support, first, the call to have the issue debated and, second, the motion that is before us today.

The bill will put in place the necessary framework to give effect to the Government's decision to sell Commonwealth Funds Management Limited (CFM) and its subsidiaries.

CFM is a wholly Commonwealth owned public company that provides investment services in the public and private sectors. Its major clients are the Boards of Trustees of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme (the CSS) and the Public Sector Superannuation (the PSS) Scheme. However, it acts as a wholesale funds manager for a number of other public and private sector funds and is involved in retail funds management for individual investors via its superannuation and general investment retail products.

CFM's functions are not part of government's core activities and for this reason and to ensure the longer term future of CFM and the best returns on the funds it has under management the Government has decided to sell the company.

CFM was created in 1991 by the transformation of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust (SFIT). SFIT had been established in 1976 as a statutory authority with trustee responsibility for the management and investment of the CSS Fund which contained the contributions of CSS members and the income earned from the investment of those contributions.

When the new PSS Scheme was established in 1990, full responsibility for that scheme and the investment of PSS Fund moneys was given to the joint employer/employee PSS Board. At the same time, the CSS Board was established, with responsibilities for the invalidity retirement process and setting the interest rate to be allocated to contributions. In 1991, the CSS Board was given responsibility for management of the CSS Fund.

The transfer of SFIT's trustee function and responsibility for the investment of the CSS Fund to the CSS Board, was accompanied by SFIT's transformation to CFM with the role of general funds manager. To assist its establishment as a funds manager, CFM was provided with legislative monopolies over the management of the CSS and PSS Funds until 30 June 1995. Since then, the CSS and PSS Boards have been free to determine their own investment management arrangements.

During the period of its monopoly, CFM worked with the CSS and PSS Boards to develop investment management arrangements to apply to the CSS and PSS Funds after 30 June 1995. The new arrangements involve CFM's subsidiary, Total Risk Management Pty Ltd (TRM), in providing advice to the Boards about the overall investment strategies for the funds. The strategies involve management of substantial "passive" cores of the funds. This is being undertaken by CFM. The balance of the CSS and PSS Funds has been progressively allocated by the CSS and PSS Boards to a number of specialist "active" funds managers who have been selected on the advice of TRM.

Although CFM has developed additional business and attracted funds from other clients, the substantial CSS and PSS funds under management still represented some 75 per cent of the total funds under CFM's direct management at 30 June 1996.

The ending of the monopolies over the CSS and PSS Funds has renewed pressures on CFM to improve its competitiveness in attracting additional clients and additional funds under management. This has come at a time when competition in the funds management industry itself has been increasing.

While the volume of funds in the market is growing, so too is the number of fund managers. In addition to traditional funds managers, there is competition from small "boutique" managers offering specialised services and from overseas managers who are establishing operations in Australia. Existing life insurance companies and banks are also seeing funds management as a source of new business.

Moreover, the growing numbers of competitors provide opportunities for CFM. Many of those competitors are facing similar pressures and it is expected that some would be interested in joining forces via a purchase of CFM. It is expected that CFM's expertise and experience will be of benefit to potential purchasers and in turn that CFM would benefit from the wider opportunities available for further development of its business

The Government's decision to sell CFM is consistent with the recommendations of the National Commission of Audit (NCOA) which considered that government business activities whose objectives are to provide goods and services on a commercial basis should only be retained in public ownership if there is a clear public interest case to do so. Against the background of a growing number and variety of funds managers, and the investment strategies of the CSS and PSS Boards, there is clearly no public interest case to retain CFM in public ownership.

In reaching its decision, the Government consulted with the Board of CFM which has fully supported this initiative. The sale process is also being undertaken in close consultation with CFM and CFM's major clients, particularly the CSS and PSS Boards of trustees. The sale of CFM should provide it with the opportunity to further improve its commercial performance and this should benefit its clients, including the Boards of the various superannuation schemes and their members.
The CFM Sale Bill provides the necessary framework to give effect to the decision to sell CFM.

The bill provides for a flexible disposal strategy. It allows for the sale of the shares in CFM and the separate sale of the shares in CFM subsidiaries on the same or different days. It enables the establishment, under Ministerial direction, of subsidiaries of CFM and the transfer of subsidiaries to Commonwealth ownership to allow their separate sale

Part 2 of the bill provides for the transfer of CFM subsidiaries to the Commonwealth. In particular, it enables the transfer of CFM's existing subsidiary, TRM, to Commonwealth ownership to facilitate sale of that company separately from the sale of CFM, if sale in that form eventuates from the tender process now under way. That approach was recommended in the scoping study prepared by the business advisers appointed by my Department.

That Part of the bill also includes provision for the transfer of CFM staff, by Ministerial declaration, to a CFM subsidiary which has been transferred under this bill. This is because at present all the staff employed in CFM's operations, including those of the subsidiary TRM, are employed by CFM. The bill provides for continuity of employment terms and conditions and accrued entitlements for CFM staff who are transferred to TRM or any other CFM subsidiary that may be created. Provision is also made for the application of certain parts of the Commonwealth Funds Management Limited Act, and certain other legislation to transferred CFM subsidiaries.
Part 3 of the bill provides for the declaration of the sale day for CFM and any transferred bodies by the Minister

Importantly, the bill provides in Part 3 for the preservation or other recognition of entitlements of CFM staff. It preserves accrued long service leave and superannuation entitlements and ensures that the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act continues to apply in relation to injury or loss incurred before sale day The bill provides for certain other rights, such as mobility rights under the Public Service Act 1922, to cease when CFM or a transferred body is sold. In these respects the bill reflects the past practice of Government in protecting accrued rights of employees in asset sale situations.

The bill also provides in Part 3 for the cancellation of CFM's franking credits, as the Government's clear advice has been that there would be no benefit to the sale process in having those credits pass to any purchaser.

Part 4 of the bill further provides for the transfer, by Ministerial declaration, of specified assets, liabilities, rights and obligations of CFM or a transferred body to specified transferees on specified days. The ability to transfer these matters in this way will allow for the sale or transfer of matters that do not constitute CFM subsidiaries and for which it would not be appropriate to establish a subsidiary. This includes the transfer of assets and liabilities to transferred bodies to enable them to be sold as separate commercial entities.

The bill amends the Commonwealth Funds Management Limited Act 1990 to remove the constraints on the sale of CFM included in section 47 of that act and provides for the removal of similar constraints from CFM's memorandum and articles of association. The bill applies relevant provisions of that act to CFM subsidiaries that are transferred to Commonwealth ownership while they are in Commonwealth ownership and provides that they will cease to apply to CFM and the transferred bodies when they are sold.
The bill also makes consequential amendments to a number of other Commonwealth acts.

This bill will provide a framework for the sale of CFM in the most flexible and expeditious way in response to commercial interest that is expressed in the sale process. It will also protect the interests of CFM employees and enable the effective disposition of assets, liabilities, rights and obligations, including for the benefit of CFM's clients.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —Indeed, these matters were dealt with fairly thoroughly yesterday. As I said in my closing remarks as we adjourned this debate in committee, I doubt whether those opposite will be satisfied with the answers they receive. But I have had further advice and I am happy to put a few matters on the record. I hope that does help Senator Jacinta Collins, who I know has a deep interest in this area of the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The requirement that the AIRC have regard to the need to apply the principle of equal pay for work of equal value, without discrimination based on sex, reflects the fact that its functions under part 6—dispute prevention and settlement—largely relate to the making of awards. The phrase `equal pay for work of equal value' is the principle developed by the AIRC to deal with the equal pay matters in the award area. As recently as November 1995, the AIRC has confirmed that this principle still applies. The principle applies and will continue to apply to all pay matters in the award stream, including to bonuses and allowances, which Senator Jacinta Collins will recall were something I responded to on Senator Mackay's queries.

It would be inappropriate for the AIRC to deal with alleged discrimination in the over‐award area in the context of its award making functions. The specific inclusion of the principle in the legislation in the context of the AIRC's award making functions strengthens current arrangements. Currently, where equal pay matters in awards are not legislated but left to the AIRC's wage fixing principles, the phrase `equal remuneration for work of equal value' has not generally been used in the context of the award stream but it was introduced through the Industrial Relations Reform Act 1993 in the context of separate minimum entitlements provisions. These provisions allow the AIRC to make orders on application to ensure equal remuneration for work of equal value for men and women workers, without discrimination based on sex, where there is no adequate alternative remedy.

BREAK.PARA: The phrase `equal remuneration' reflects the words used in the ILO equal remuneration convention on which the provisions are based. The use of the word `remuneration' indicates that the provisions have the potential to deal with a broader range of matters than have normally been addressed in the award stream—in particular, over‐award pay. Remuneration is defined in the ILO convention as `including the ordinary, basic or minimum wage or salary and any additional emoluments whatsoever payable directly or indirectly, whether in cash or in kind, by the employer to the worker and arising out of the worker's employment'. That is something I expect Senator Jacinta Collins would have known already. Through a combination of provisions, including those set out in proposed section 88B and the minimum entitlements and equal remuneration provisions, legislation will be comprehensive in its coverage of equal pay. The AIRC will be able to deal with the full range of equal pay issues in both the award and over‐award areas.

—For the time being perhaps, but what I do not appreciate and what perhaps this point reflects is that the government's agenda has been to narrow awards as far as they possibly could but, in doing so, they are caught in this trap because what they are left with in awards at the moment are things beyond just basic pay, such as superannuation and redundancy pay, which do not fit within the established industrial principle with respect to how pay is regarded.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate the parliamentary secretary's offer to take this on notice but my understanding—and someone might correct me on procedure—is that if we want to move along with this bill, we need to deal with the amendments on this issue now. I call again: rather than just taking this issue on notice, let the opposition's amendment in relation to equal remuneration—I particularly call on the Democrats—be supported.

—This will be the final point on this because, with all due respect, we are being extremely circular and we are not getting any satisfaction at all from the government on this point. SPEECH.PARA: This is the last time I will stand on this issue but I want to simply say that the answers given on this have been completely inadequate. TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)
